tasks.task: Conduct mob grazing as a management intensive intensive grazing technique to improve soil health and vegetation.
subtasks: Maintain high stocking densities (20-25,000 to 200,000+ pounds live weight per acre).
Frequently move livestock (daily to several times a day) to trample and consume forage.
Observe and document soil health improvement and vegetation diversity.
Calculate harvest efficiency (consumption + trampling) and optimize stocking densities for maximum benefit.
Adapt management practices based on local rainfall and vegetation.
Monitor livestock performance (body condition, gains) during intensive grazing periods.
Rotate paddocks to allow extended rest periods (up to a year) before next use.
Use visual and clipping transect data to assess utilization and biomass changes.
Implement rinsing and recovery protocols for livestock movement (e.g., water arena setups).

tasks.task: Conduct economic analysis of mob grazing practices.
subtasks: Evaluate the economic feasibility and return on investment of higher harvest efficiency.
Compare short-term labor costs with long-term productivity gains.
Assess potential for increased carrying capacity and compensatory gain.
Use economic models to determine optimal stocking densities and return rates.
Understand the impact of high grazing pressure on plant regrowth (e.g., boot stage vs. headed-out plants).
Monitor soil carbon levels and adjust practices for potential long-term benefits.
Consider the balance between trampling and root growth (taller plants generally indicate stronger root systems).
